awd_titl_txt: Graph-Based Regularization Techniques and Their Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid development of science and technology ushers in a new era of big data that requires developing specialized algorithms to process a large amount of data. Signal processing and other related techniques aim to recover signals of interest or some of their properties; this goal can be reduced to an optimization question. Due to physical limitations of hardware, the size of the acquired data is in general much smaller than that of the underlying signal, resulting in an ill-posed problem for signal recovery with infinitely many solutions. Regularization techniques have been developed to address this inherent ill-posedness. Despite being widely applied in low-dimensional signal processing, regularization has seen limited use in processing high-dimensional data sets, especially those best represented by graphs, that is, networks with sophisticated connections. This project aims to further develop graph-based regularization techniques, with potential to revolutionize imaging and data analysis technologies in many areas of data science.

This project aims to develop a useful graph-based regularization framework for various signal processing problems, to address major theoretical and computational challenges for its applications, to provide new interpretations of low-dimensional regularization techniques, and to demonstrate its capability for handling large-scale data sets. The research has three objectives: (1) Develop novel graph-based regularization techniques along with rigorous theoretical guarantees to handle the more challenging signal processing problems and related inverse problems; (2) Develop efficient numerical algorithms to solve the corresponding optimization problems; and (3) Conduct numerical experiments in imaging applications to demonstrate the advantages of the proposed approaches in terms of accuracy and efficiency. The research aims to improve data processing techniques and to infuse new insights into mathematical signal and image processing, with a variety of applications such as medical imaging and remote sensing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed graph regularization techniques to solve data recovery and processing problems arising in various fields, such as medical imaging, remote sensing and robotic applications. It creates new data analytical tools, generates new validation data sets, enhances existing methodologies, and influences future research directions in data science and data analytics.


This project provides multiple intellectual contributions. First, it advances the development of graph theory by developing novel graph regularization techniques for imaging applications. Specifically, graph total variation regularized approaches were created to tackle the electroencephalogram (EEG) source localization problem from single-frame to multi-frame scenarios. In addition, this framework has been expanded to develope graph total variation regularized blind hyperspectral unmixing methods and dual-graph regularized models for moving object detection and time-varying graph signal recovery. The project also contributes to the field of optimization by designing fast numerical algorithms for nonlinear optimization problems based on matrix or tensor decompositions. These innovative approaches enhance the representation of complex structures and relationships, making graph-based methods more effective in handling large-scale, high-dimensional data. Furthermore, the techniques developed from this project provide insights into integrating and fusing diverse data sources, which is valuable across a wide spectrum of data-driven applications. Lastly, the project has produced publicly accessible benchmark data sets for evaluating the performance of moving object detection in robotics and computer vision, as well as blind hyperspectral unmixing and nonblind image deblurring toolboxes.


This project integrates cutting-edge techniques such as graph theory, inverse problems, optimization and mathematical imaging, which help participants develop advanced computational and analytical skills. These research experiences prepare students for careers in data science, imaging, and other interdisciplinary fields that require both theory and applied expertise. Moreover, exposure to a broad range of disciplines fosters interdisciplinary knowledge, making the students more versatile and better prepared for careers in both academia and industry. Thus far, two undergraduate students who were mentored by the PI secured engineering positions in industry after graduation. Through hands-on experience, students gained technical skills in graph regularizations, hyperspectral imaging, and computer vision, while also honing their problem-solving, independent research and teamwork skills. Mentorship further strengthens their critical thinking, communication and collaboration abilities, which are essential for success in their careers.


The PI has actively disseminated the project's findings and results through organizing special sessions or mini-symposiums at various research meetings, including Joint Mathematics Meetings, Association for Women in Mathematics Research Symposium and SIAM Conference on Imaging Science, fostering collaboration among researchers, students and professionals.
